title: R42621
content: Facing pressure to reduce the federal budget deficit, some in the 112th Congress saw international affairs spending, including foreign aid, as expendable. Others believed a strong foreign affairs budget was crucial for national security and foreign policy goals, potentially saving money by avoiding costly military interventions. Congress considered budget cuts to address costs. Congress considered the FY2013 Department of State, Foreign Operations, and Related Agencies appropriations in the context of the Budget Control Act of 2011, delaying passing most appropriations bills until after the start of the new fiscal year. The House passed legislation (H.R. 933) on March 6, 2013, to fund federal programs. The House passed legislation (H.R. 933) on March 6, 2013, to fund federal programs for the remainder of FY2013, which was signed into law on March 26, 2013 (P.L. 113-6). This included the State-Foreign Operations appropriation, supporting international affairs programs and activities. The international affairs budget (Function 150) covers various programs and activities, such as foreign economic and security assistance, contributions to international organizations, State Department and USAID operations, public diplomacy, and international broadcasting. However, some programs like food aid and certain commissions are funded through different appropriations bills. The Trade Commission and Foreign Claims Settlement Commission, funded through the Commerce-Science-Justice appropriation, are international affairs programs not funded through the State-Foreign Operations appropriations bill. International commissions like the International Boundary and Water Commission are funded through the State-Foreign Operations bill. A chart illustrating the organizational structure of the State-Foreign Operations appropriations bill is provided in Appendix A. Abbreviations of terms used throughout this report are in Appendix B. During the Cold War, foreign aid and diplomatic programs focused on anti-communism, economic development, trade promotion, education, health care, human rights, and environmental protection. Post-Cold War, the focus shifted to broader policy interests. Since the early 1990s, U.S. foreign policy objectives shifted to include stopping nuclear weapons proliferation, curbing illegal drug production, promoting peace in the Middle East, achieving regional stability, protecting religious freedom, and countering human trafficking. The focus further changed after the 9/11 attacks to emphasize national security objectives in foreign aid and diplomatic programs.
